    Release Notes

    v1.3.2 Release Notes

    v1.3.1 Release Notes
    • Removed unused symbols
    v1.3.0 Release Notes
    • Adding in-app store view. Now, users don't leave the app if they want to download the advertising app from the post roll. (Requires linking StoreKit.framework)(#37289419)
    • Added identifierForAdvertising support (Requires linking AdSupport.framework) (#40979547)
    • Device model specific targeting (#40986131)
    • Performance improvements
    • Speeding up downloading of videos
    • Added mute button functionality. See here for more details.
    Older releases...
    v1.2.1 Release Notes
    • Fixing memory leak where VGVunglePub's playModalAd did not release UIViewController object after retaining it.
    v1.2.0 Release Notes
    • Bug Fix - fixing video playback instabilities in iOS 5.x if background music is playing.
    • VGVunglePub.h API addition - +(void)muteIfMusicPlaying:(BOOL)state; to allow the developer to control the audio playback mode if we detect background music is playing. If state is set to TRUE, the video's audio channel will be muted. If set to FALSE, the video audio channel will be blended with the background music.
    v1.1.6 Release Notes
    • Optimized ad delivery for slower devices on low throughput networks
    v1.1.5 Release Notes Suppports armv7s ( iPhone 5 )
    • Added architecture armv7s

    Architectures in the fat file: libvunglepub.a are: armv7 (cputype (12) cpusubtype (11)) i386

    Overview

    Before you start...

    This is a code library that allows you to enhance your iOS applications with videos from Vungle.

    When your program starts, the VunglePub SDK will begin downloading a video in the background and save it to disk. There are different kinds of videos that the pub SDK may download. This depends on what kind of campaign you have set up on the dashboard.

    When you're ready to display an ad, you can call an SDK method that will tell you if an ad is ready to be played or not. If there is an ad that's ready to go, then you can call an SDK method that will present the ad modally over one of your existing view controllers. When the user has finished interacting with the ad, control will return to your app's view controller, and you can resume normal user interaction.

    Types of Videos
    • Upsell Videos (video that promote your free app to your paid app)
    • Cross Promotional Videos (video that promotes apps that you have set up to advertise in your suite of apps)
    • External

    The SDK will only present videos when they have been fully downloaded to disk. That means that there is no possibility that the ad will pause partway through due to a poor network connection. Ads will only be displayed when the user's device has a working internet connection, which is needed for displaying the ad's payload contents. After an appropriate amount of time has elapsed, cached videos will be erased, freeing up disk space.

    Instances where you do not want to integrate the Vungle Pub SDK


    Our SDK empowers all mobile apps with the ability to display videos that are the most compatible for your customers' devices. The Vungle Pub SDK should only be integrated in your apps that require this ability.

    If you are advertising your app through Vungle, you'll need to add:
    Download Attribution

    Add the download attribution API if you want to:

    • Advertise but not publish through Vungle
    • Track installs of your app

    Looking for the unity plugin? Download it here:

    Vungle Unity Plugin

    Integrating the SDK

    Runtime Requirements

    Apps built with the VunglePub library, including the VunglePub test app, will run on Apple's hardware devices running iOS 3.2 or later, and also in the iOS device simulator. All iPads, iPhones, and iPod Touch devices are supported, provided that they are running iOS 3.1 or later.

    Details ...

    If a device is running iOS 4.3 or later, then video ads are displayed with the iOS class AVPlayer.

    Build-time Requirements

    Building an iOS app that includes the VunglePub SDK works in Xcode 3.x and Xcode 4.x. All recent-ish versions of Xcode should work fine. You must build your app with the iOS SDK version 4.x or 5.x.

    VunglePub SDK and its associated libraries do not use Automatic Reference Counting (ARC). You can integrate the code into either ARC or non-ARC apps.

    Adding the VunglePub SDK to your project

    To integrate the VunglePub SDK into your iOS application, you should get the "App ID" from your application's page on the Vungle Dashboard. If you haven't set that up yet, then you can register your Application Here. If this is only a test app, then you can use the "vungleTest" app ID for testing purposes, but be sure to not release that into the wild!

    1. Linking the vungle pub library

    The VunglePub SDK is provided to you as a single binary, libvunglepub.a, and associated header files. This is a library that contains executable code for arm6 and arm7 hardware devices and the iOS simulator. It must be linked to your app in your Xcode project.

    2. Adding Graphical Assets

    The VunglePub SDK has one directory of graphical assets that must be added to your project, so that it can properly display its buttons.

    3. Linking required frameworks

    • AVFoundation.framework
    • CFNetwork.framework
    • CoreGraphics.framework
    • AudioToolbox.framework
    • CoreMedia.framework
    • Foundation.framework
    • libz.dylib
    • MediaPlayer.framework
    • QuartzCore.framework
    • SystemConfiguration.framework
    • UIKit.framework
    • AdSupport.framework new (v1.2.2)
    • StoreKit.framework new (v1.2.2)
    • CoreLocation.framework (Location is only used when you specifically enable it in locationEnabled) Required ★

    3. Modify "Other Linker Flags"

    In your Xcode project settings, find the field called "Other Linker Flags." Add the following text, if it's not already there:

    -ObjC -all_load

    If your project cannot specify -all_load, you can also use this flag to only load our static library's code:

    -force_load{path_to_libvunglepub.a}

    This must be added for all configurations: Debug, Release, and any others you might have.

    This step is needed due to a quirk in the Objective-C language that makes it difficult or impossible to know which parts of a static library should be linked with your program. By adding these flags, all code found in static libraries will be linked in.

    This step is needed for any Xcode project that links with Objective-C static libraries. Without it, your app will likely crash at runtime.

    Detailed Instructions
    XCode 3

    To set up linker flags in XCode 3, navigate to the "Build" tab of the project info window. If you do not see "OTHER_LDFLAGS", try restarting xcode. If it is still not there, then navigate to the settings icon in the lower left corner. Click on "Add User-Defined Setting". This will add a new item to the full list of settings, where you get to type in the setting name on the left and the value on the right.

    Add this on the left: OTHER_LDFLAGSand this on the right: -ObjC -all_load

    XCode 4

    To set up linker flags in XCode 4, and go to your project settings. Find "Other Linker Flags" in the linker section and if you dont see the flags-ObjC -all_loadalready there, then add the following flag-force_load {path_to_libvunglepub.a}(without the curly,{}, brackets) there. The path should be relative to the folder that contains the .xcodeproj file for your application.

    4. Add the main header file

    Finally, the VunglePub SDK main header file must be added to your app. It is suggested that you add this line to your prefix header:

    #import <vunglepub/vunglepub.h>

    This is commonly called the [project_name]-Prefix.pch file. Then, add the VunglePub SDK's parent directory to your project's header search paths.

    If you perform all these steps and your project builds and links without any warnings or errors, then you have succeeded. If you have problems, look to the Vungle test app for guidance. It is an example app which correctly uses the VunglePub SDK to display video assets.

    VunglePub SDK initialization and shutdown

    VunglePub SDK must be initialized before use. A good place to do this is in your application delegate's startup method named:
    -(BOOL)application:(UIApplication*)application
didFinishLaunchingWithOptions:(NSDictionary*)launchOptions

    SDK initialization

    Here is an example method that properly starts the VunglePub SDK:

    -(void)vungleStart
{
    VGUserData*  data  = [VGUserData defaultUserData];
    NSString*    appID = @"Your App ID Here";
    
    // set up config data
    data.age             = 36;
    data.gender          = VGGenderFemale;
    data.adOrientation   = VGAdOrientationLandscape;
    data.locationEnabled = TRUE;
    
    // start vungle publisher library
    [VGVunglePub startWithPubAppID:appID userData:data];
}

    The members of the VGUserData object are described in greater detail in a later section of this document.

    SDK shutdown

    When your app is closing, the VunglePub SDK should be given an opportunity to shut itself down properly. A good place to do this is in your application delegate's applicationWillTerminate: method. Here's an example:

    -(void)applicationWillTerminate:(UIApplication*)application
{
    [VGVunglePub stop];
}

    When your app is run on iOS 4.0 or later, the app delegate's termination method is usually not called. So this particular exit route is mostly for devices running iOS versions earlier than 4.0. For iOS 4.0 and later, VunglePub uses an alternate method to ensure that it is shut down appropriately, which does not require any intervention on your part.

    Post Integration

    When the VunglePub SDK is initialized, you must provide it with some data about your app. The primary piece of information is your Vungle App ID, a string which uniquely identifies your app. This string is provided by the Vungle Dashboard. All other configuration information is supplied via the VGUserData object, which you must have filled out before you attempt to start VunglePub.

    If you haven't set up your app id yet on the dashboard , ping tech-support@vungle.com to get one, or log on to the dashboard and add your app to our system.

    VGUserData initialization

    To begin, get a new VGUserData filled out with default data, like this:

    VGUserData*  data = [VGUserData defaultData];

    It's acceptable to pass this data object directly to the VunglePub library without making any modifications. But if you like, you can set any or all of the following fields:

  • data.age and data.gender

    • The age and gender of the person using your app, if that information is known. If supplied, Vungle will be able to provide you with suitably targeted videos.

  • data.adOrientation

    • Should be set to VGAdOrientationPortrait or VGAdOrientationLandscape, which indicates that you'd prefer videos in either portrait or landscape orientations. This is only a hint. We can't guarantee that all videos will be supplied in the given orientation.

  • data.locationEnabled

    • If set to TRUE, then your user's latitude/longitude coordinates will be sent with every ad request. If enabled, Vungle will be able to send you videos that are geographically targeted.

    Displaying a video ad

    When your app has reached a suitable stopping point, you can ask the VunglePub SDK whether it has an ad ready to display by calling this method:

    +[VGVunglePub adIsAvailable]

    If it returns TRUE, then at least one ad has been completely downloaded to disk and is ready for display. FALSE means that there are no videos to display at this time.Note that this method will only return TRUE when the iOS device is connected to the internet.

    If an ad is ready to display, you can call this method:

    +[VGVunglePub playModalAd:(UIViewController*)controller animated:(BOOL)animated]

    'controller' is a pointer to one of your app's view controllers that will be the parent of the video ad. If 'animated' is TRUE, then the ad view controller will slide up from the bottom of the screen. When the user has finished interacting with your ad, the Vungle view controller will disappear and you can resume normal operation.

    Incentivized Views

    If you are interested in including incentivized view mechanics into your game or application, you can use the delegates and the helper methods to further boost your monetization efforts.

    Here are some steps you can take:

    1. Check whether a video is available by calling +[VGVunglePub adIsAvailable]
    2. Determine if the user is economically viable to be monetized via incentivized views.
    3. Offer a video view for some virtual currency.Watch this 15 second video and receive 5 gold coins!
    4. Start the vungle video
    5. In your vungleMoviePlayedfunction which is implemented by theVGVunglePubDelegate, you can use the VGPlayData object to call -(BOOL)playedFull which tells you if the full movie was watched by the user.
    6. If the returned value is TRUE, that means the whole movie was watched, so you can then set a flag in your app to designate that the view was completed.
    7. In yourvungleViewDidDisappear delegate method, check to see if the view was completed, then proceed to reward the user. This delegate is fired after the ad is completely finished.

    We also have a special method to call incentivized ads:

    +[VGVunglePub +(void)playIncentivizedAd:(UIViewController*)controller animated:(BOOL)animated showClose:(BOOL)flag userTag:(NSString *)user]

    This is very similar to playModalAd except, it has an extra showClose flag which if set to FALSE, disables the close button during the video and if set to TRUE, enables the close button. This call when used, can generate a callback from our server to a url of your choice which can be set in the dashboard page for your app. You can also set the userTag to identify the user that generated the callback or leave it as nil, if you do not want to do so.

    Advanced Options
    Allowing Auto Rotation

    If you would like the video to freely rotate to the device's orientation, you can set this property: 

    [VGVunglePub allowAutoRotate:TRUE];

    This would keep your users from rotating the device from landscape to portrait (and vice versa) to properly view the video ad.

    Muting video ads if background music is playing

    Some apps take control of the audio channel if background music is playing. Set:

    [VGVunglePub muteIfMusicPlaying:TRUE];

    This will prevent the video from disrupting your users' background audio listening experience.

    All done!

    Hopefully that was really easy to do. There are other things you can do with the SDK to better inform your app of what is going on.

    Vungle SDK delegate

    The app can be informed of interesting events by setting a delegate object. Call this method:

    +[VGVunglePub setDelegate:(VGVungleDelegate)delegate]

    Your delegate can implement some or all of these methods:

    -(void)vungleMoviePlayed:(VGPlayData*)playData;
-(void)vungleStatusUpdate:(VGStatusData*)statusData;
-(void)vungleViewDidDisappear:(UIViewController*)viewController;
-(void)vungleViewWillAppear:(UIViewController*)viewController;

    The first method is called when a video ad has finished playing. You can inspect the member variables of the VGPlayData object to determine how long the ad was and how much of the ad was viewed by the user. This method might be called more than once per ad, if the user decides to watch the ad a second time.

    The second method is called with status updates. You can examine the provided VGStatusData object for information on how many videos are cached to disk, how many are available to be played, and so on. Keep in mind that, even if Vungle has cached ads, it will not display them unless the device is connected to the internet.

    The last two methods are called before Vungle's ad view controller appears and after it disappears. 'viewController' will be a pointer to Vungle's ad view controller. You should not make any assumptions about this object, other than it is a standard UIViewController.

    Other

    Configuring Video Cache Size

    You can control how much disk space the Vungle SDK will use as a cache. Use these methods:

    [VGVunglePub cacheSizeGet]  
[VGVunglePub cacheSizeSet:(NSInteger)megabytes]

    The default cache size is 20MB. Note that Vungle cached ads and all other files it uses are stored in an iOS cache directory. That means the files will not be backed up or synced, and they may be automatically purged by the device if it is running low on disk space.

    The size of the videos range from 0.5-2MB, approximately, with the average video size being 1.5MB. Our SDK automatically purges ads that are cached, but not viewed, after 24 hours to ensure that the highest yielding ads for that day get shown. However ads that remain in the cache can be viewed several times, as long as it's within the 24h period.

    Allowing autorotation of videos

    The ad view defaults to the orientation of the video. However, if you would like to allow the user to rotate the device freely, you can use the following method to enable this.

    + (void)allowAutoRotate:(BOOL)allow;

    Configuring logs to stdout

    +[VGVunglePub logToStdout:TRUE]

    then it will print various bits of status info to the terminal. If you want to get really involved, you can call this method:

    +[VGVunglePub logTarget:(id)target action:(SEL)action]

    which sets a target/action pair that will be called for every line of terminal output that the VunglePub SDK produces. The action method should have a signature similar to this:

    -(void)vungleLogLine:(NSString*)logLine

    The Vungle test app takes advantage of this feature to display Vungle terminal output in a UITextView.

    Customizing countdown text during video play

    If you would like to customize the countdown text that appears at the top of a video after it reaches its minimum view point, you can use:

    +[VGVunglePub (BOOL)setCustomCountDownText:(NSString*)text]

    This has a maximum character limit of 15, since we automatically append " in x seconds" to the end of this text. It returns TRUE if the text provided was within the limit and FALSE otherwise.

    Customizing alert view

    If the user tries to close an incentivized video, you can add customize the alert box that appears by using:

    +[VGVunglePub (void)alertBoxWithTitle:(NSString*)title Body:(NSString*)body leftButtonTitle:(NSString*)button1 rightButtonTitle:(NSString*)button2]

    Video playback volume

    The Vungle SDK will not alter the device's volume level. Videos will be played at the volume set by the user with the hardware volume buttons.

    If the device playing the video is running iOS 4.3 or later, the ad will have a mute button that can be pressed to suppress audio output.

    Muting Videos

    Starting in v1.3.0 you have the option to mute the videos in the ads. Users still have the ability to unmute the videos by tapping on the speaker icon in the video playback view.

    To enabled muted video playback you can set the following to TRUE:

    [VGVunglePub setSoundEnabled:FALSE];

    Troubleshooting

    If you run into problems, please contact tech-support@vungle.com

    Notes

    Internally, the Vungle Pub SDK makes use of the following libraries:

    • SBJson 3.0
    • MiniZip 1.1
    • SSZipArchive 0.1.2

    All publicly-visible symbol names have been changed to start with VG, vg, vg_, or similar. We did this so that if you use one of these libraries in your app, your copy will not conflict with the Vungle Pub SDK's internal copy.

    Upgrading to the newest version of the SDK

    If you have an older version of the SDK, you can follow these steps to upgrade:

    • Extract the contents of the new SDK
    • Remove the old vunglepub folder from your XCode project
    • Add the new vunglepub folder to the XCode project so that the bin, headers, and resources folders are updated.

    Size of binary

    If you're wondering about the size of the .a static library, see this awesome Stack Overflow article.

    !#$% it! Lets do it live!

    We will automatically toggle the live ads once we detect a certain amount of unique devices using the app after implementing our SDK. This should happen very shortly after the app going 'live' in the app store, so you needn't worry about the switch from test mode to active status.

    If you still haven't seen this switch after more than 30 installs have happened off the live version of the game, please contact your account manager or account-managers@vungle.com and we will be happy to assist you.
